snippet: Mary Wittenberg, director of the New York City Marathon, realized that many did not see the race as a help, but rather as an insensitive romp through the wounds of a natural disaster.
abstract: Analysis; New York City Marathon director Mary Wittenberg bears brunt of criticism for delayed decision to cancel race in wake of Hurricane Sandy; Wittenberg had initially planned to carry on with the marathon, arguing that it would help the city financially, but decided to cancel at last minute due to widespread opposition.

byline.original: By JULIET MACUR and KEN BELSON

lead_paragraph: Mary Wittenberg, director of the New York City Marathon, realized that many did not see the race as a help, but rather as an insensitive romp through the wounds of a natural disaster.

headline.seo: New York City Marathon Director’s Difficult Decision to Cancel Race
headline.main: Wittenberg’s Actions Met Head On by Critics
headline.print_headline: Wittenberg’s Actions Met Head On by Critics
